data.text: To prepare (food) for eating by applying heat.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To prepare or treat by heating.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To alter or falsify so as to make a more favorable impression; doctor.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: disreputable accountants who were paid to cook the firm's books.

data.text: To prepare food for eating by applying heat.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To undergo application of heat especially for the purpose of later ingestion.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To happen, develop, or take place.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To proceed or perform very well.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: The band really got cooking after midnight.

data.text: A person who prepares food for eating.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: The speeding ticket cooked his goose with his father. Her goose was cooked when she was caught cheating on the test.
